transcription.text: Production props of a  cast of prosthetics teeth, top and bottom sets of human teeth clamped into a stand

"Simply being in the presence of a giant Sequoia tree catalyses an experience that embeds us in planetary cycles and shared natural rhythms. If you could explore yourself, you would discover that just under your skin you are a branching being made of rivers, whirlpools and ripples in the tides of existence. Bringing the invisible into this view and exploring the symbiosis of everything can transform our understanding of the world – and how we interact with it.”
- Robin McNicholas of Marshmallow Laser Feast

transcription.text: Director George Miller didn’t waste anytime giving cinemagoers everything they loved from the original Mad Max and more! After the deaths of his wife and child, Max (Mel Gibson) wanders the post-apocalyptic Australian outback, nomadically navigating a landscape descended into tribal warfare. The bare minimal plot was (mostly) abandoned for spectacular high speed chases that make it a must see for all action fans. Miller matched then quickly exceeded expectations with this breakneck sequel to the genre original. The films startling use of the arid outback and perverse costuming again set the benchmark for other genre films, especially in the US and Europe where it spawned many imitations and is still referenced to this day in film, music video and fashion. Again Miller ups the ante with the white-knuckled practical stunts which he would go on to perfect in the award-winning Mad Max: Fury Road.
Cast moulds showing the stages in prosthetic creation; representing a human bust with a  prosthetic head, face and hands for a characters transformation into a witch.

transcription.text:
4 x VHS tapes in stack with the cover titles:
Ananguku Video (top video)
Nganampa Anwernekenhe
Aboriginal Video Magazine
Ernabella Video

Taking an unexpected direction from the genre Miller established with his highly influential previous films, Mad Max: Beyond Thunderdome finds our reluctant hero coming face-to-face with the feudal Aunty Entity (Tina Turner), who lords over Bartertown and the deadly battle arena, Thunderdome. Less emphasis on car chases and more on the brutal tribal world Aunty Entity and her minions reign over, the film sees Max leading a band of feral orphans to freedom. Never fear though, Beyond Thunderdome still bristles with mind-boggling retro-fitted cars, hair-raising stunt work, bizarre costumes and intricate world building to make this third entry into the series as white-knuckled as its predecessors.

Leather custom case housing a 16mm Bell and Howell Company film camera, and a Weston Master Universal Exposure Meter with 2 accompanying booklets housed in their original cardboard storage box.
